issues.title: ENV
issues.message: Manual review is required to ensure that ENV instructions are used efficiently and do not lead to unnecessary intermediate layers, especially when setting and unsetting variables within the same Dockerfile.
issues.suggestion: Use ENV to set environment variables and update the PATH to facilitate software execution. Avoid creating unnecessary layers by combining ENV instructions where possible. For setting and unsetting environment variables within the same layer, consider using a RUN instruction with shell commands.

issues.title: Rebuild your images often
issues.message: Due to the linter's limitations, it cannot verify if images are being rebuilt often or if the --no-cache option is used during builds. This requires understanding of the build process and context beyond what is specified in the Dockerfile.
issues.suggestion: Ensure to rebuild your Docker images frequently to incorporate updated dependencies and base images. Consider using the --no-cache option during builds to avoid using cached layers and ensure a fresh download of dependencies and base images. Additionally, consider pinning your base image to a specific version to avoid unexpected changes.

issues.title: Create ephemeral containers
issues.message: This check requires manual review to ensure that the Dockerfile instructions do not create unnecessary dependencies or stateful components within the container, which would make it less ephemeral. For example, avoiding instructions that write data to the container filesystem in a way that is expected to persist across container restarts.
issues.suggestion: Ensure your Dockerfile creates containers that can be easily stopped, destroyed, and replaced, minimizing setup and configuration. Avoid writing data to the container's filesystem that needs to persist across restarts, and instead use external data stores or services for any stateful components.

issues.title: Choose the right base image
issues.message: Manual review required to ensure the base image is from a trusted source and is minimal for the application's requirements.
issues.suggestion: Avoid using the 'latest' tag for base images to ensure reproducibility. Consider using a minimal base image like 'scratch' or a specific version of an official image that suits your application's needs. Review your Dockerfile to ensure you're using a trusted and minimal base image for both development/build stages and a separate, slimmer image for production. Consider multi-stage builds to minimize the final image size.

issues.title: Sort multi-line arguments
issues.message: Due to the linter's limitations in understanding context across multiple lines and the complexity of verifying alphanumeric sorting of multi-line arguments, this check requires manual review.
issues.suggestion: Ensure that multi-line arguments, such as package lists in a RUN instruction, are sorted alphanumerically. This facilitates easier maintenance and review. Additionally, include a space before a backslash (\) at the end of each line for better readability.

issues.title: ONBUILD
issues.message: Manual review is required to ensure that images built with ONBUILD instructions have a separate tag, such as ruby:1.9-onbuild or ruby:2.0-onbuild, to mitigate potential build context issues and to follow best practices.
issues.suggestion: Avoid using ADD or COPY instructions directly in ONBUILD to prevent build failures due to missing resources. Consider adding a separate tag for images built with ONBUILD instructions to facilitate better version control and mitigate potential issues.

issues.title: ADD or COPY
issues.message: Determining if COPY is used appropriately for copying files from one stage to another in a multi-stage build requires understanding the Dockerfile's structure and context, which is beyond this linter's capabilities.
issues.suggestion: Prefer using COPY for copying local files. Use ADD only for its unique features like adding files from remote URLs and auto-extracting tar files.

issues.title: EXPOSE
issues.message: Due to the linter's limitations, it cannot verify if the exposed port matches the common, traditional port for the specific application being containerized. This requires manual review.
issues.suggestion: Ensure you are using the EXPOSE instruction to indicate the common, traditional port for your application. For example, use EXPOSE 80 for Apache web server images, and EXPOSE 27017 for MongoDB images. This facilitates easier understanding and management of container networking.

issues.title: Create reusable stages
issues.message: Manual review is required to ensure that reusable stages are created for components shared across multiple images, as this cannot be determined by simple line-by-line analysis or without understanding the context of the Dockerfile's structure and the relationship between stages.
issues.suggestion: Consider organizing your Dockerfile to include a base stage that contains components shared across multiple images. Then, use this base stage as a starting point for other stages to avoid duplication and improve efficiency.

issues.title: USER
issues.message: Manual review is required to ensure that a non-root user is created and used correctly without frequent switching back and forth between users.
issues.suggestion: Ensure that your Dockerfile specifies a non-root user for running the service by using the USER instruction. Avoid using 'sudo' due to its unpredictable behavior. If necessary, consider alternatives like 'gosu' for privilege escalation. Also, avoid frequently switching users to reduce complexity and potential security risks.

issues.title: Use multi-stage builds
issues.message: Manual review is required to ensure that each stage in a multi-stage build is used effectively, with unnecessary files not being copied to the final image.
issues.suggestion: Split your Dockerfile into multiple stages by using multiple FROM instructions. Each stage can use a different base image, or the same one with different build contexts. Ensure that only the necessary artifacts are moved to the final stage to keep the image size small.

issues.title: FROM
issues.message: Due to the linter's limitations, it cannot verify if an image is an official Docker image or assess the full context of image selection. Manual review is required to ensure the used base image is the current official version and to verify it's the most appropriate choice for the project's needs.
issues.suggestion: Use an official Alpine image as the base for your Dockerfile to minimize size and maintain security. Avoid using the 'latest' tag to ensure your builds are predictable and reproducible. For non-Alpine images, manually verify that you're using the official version and consider its appropriateness for your project.

issues.title: Leverage build cache
issues.message: Due to the linter's limitations, it cannot analyze the order of instructions or their implications on the Docker build cache. Optimizing Dockerfile instructions for cache utilization requires understanding the context and order of instructions, which must be manually reviewed.
issues.suggestion: Review Dockerfile instructions to ensure they are ordered in a way that maximizes the use of the Docker build cache. For example, instructions that are less likely to change should be placed before instructions that are more likely to change.

issues.title: RUN
issues.message: Due to the linter's limitations, it cannot verify if 'apt-get update' and 'apt-get install' are combined in the same RUN statement or if version pinning is used for package installation. These practices need to be manually reviewed.
issues.suggestion: Ensure complex or long RUN commands are split across multiple lines for readability. Use backslashes to continue commands on a new line and chain commands with '&&'. For package installations, always combine 'apt-get update' with 'apt-get install' in the same RUN statement to avoid caching issues. Consider using version pinning for packages to ensure the build retrieves a specific version.

issues.title: Don't install unnecessary packages
issues.message: Determining if a package is unnecessary requires understanding the application's architecture and the purpose of the image. This cannot be accurately determined with simple line-by-line checks or without context.
issues.suggestion: Review the list of packages being installed and remove any that are not directly required for your application or service to run. Consider using multi-stage builds to include only the necessary artifacts in your final image.

issues.title: Build and test your images in CI
issues.message: This check requires verifying if a CI/CD pipeline like GitHub Actions is configured to automatically build and test Docker images upon code commits or pull requests. Such verification goes beyond the capabilities of a simple line-by-line Dockerfile linter and involves external tooling and configuration checks.
issues.suggestion: Ensure your project's CI/CD pipeline (e.g., GitHub Actions, GitLab CI/CD) is configured to automatically build and test your Docker images whenever changes are pushed to your source control or when a pull request is made.
